Introduction

Freddy Hernández

2018-12-15

Source: vignettes/Introduction.Rmd
Introduction.Rmd

cub distribution

require(cubm)
## Loading required package: cubm
set.seed(1234)
y <- rcub(n=100, pi=0.15, xi=0.60, m=5)
mod1 <- cub(pi.fo=y ~ 1, xi.fo=~ 1, m=5, optimizer='nlminb')
# Summary table
summary(mod1)
## ---------------------------------------------------------------
## Fixed effects for probit(pi) 
## ---------------------------------------------------------------
##             Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)
## (Intercept) -1.13453    0.73291  -1.548   0.1216
## ---------------------------------------------------------------
## Fixed effects for probit(xi) 
## ---------------------------------------------------------------
##             Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)
## (Intercept)  0.21742    0.45876  0.4739   0.6356
## ---------------------------------------------------------------
# To obtain the fitted parameters in the appropiate scale
# we need to apply the inverse link function to the fitted parameters
pnorm(mod1$par)
## (Intercept) (Intercept) 
##   0.1282861   0.5860587

# Using logit link function
mod2 <- cub(pi.fo=y ~ 1, xi.fo=~ 1, m=5, optimizer='nlminb',
            pi.link='logit', xi.link='logit')
# Summary table
summary(mod2)
## Warning in sqrt(diag(solve(object$Hessian))): Se han producido NaNs
## ---------------------------------------------------------------
## Fixed effects for logit(pi) 
## ---------------------------------------------------------------
##             Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)
## (Intercept)  -1.9162     3.3322 -0.5751   0.5653
## ---------------------------------------------------------------
## Fixed effects for logit(xi) 
## ---------------------------------------------------------------
##             Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)
## (Intercept)  0.34771    5.28963  0.0657   0.9476
## ---------------------------------------------------------------
# To obtain the fitted parameters in the appropiate scale we need
# to apply the inverse link function (logit) to the fitted parameters
1 / (1 + exp(-mod2$par))
## (Intercept) (Intercept) 
##   0.1282864   0.5860619

# Using DEoptim optimizer, it is slower but it gives good results
mod3 <- cub(pi.fo=y ~ 1, xi.fo=~ 1, m=5,
            optimizer='DEoptim', trace=50, itermax=300)
## Iteration: 50 bestvalit: 160.594019 bestmemit:   -1.145028    0.225495
## Iteration: 100 bestvalit: 160.593789 bestmemit:   -1.134458    0.217483
## Iteration: 150 bestvalit: 160.593789 bestmemit:   -1.134527    0.217418
## Iteration: 200 bestvalit: 160.593789 bestmemit:   -1.134528    0.217418
## Iteration: 250 bestvalit: 160.593789 bestmemit:   -1.134528    0.217418
## Iteration: 300 bestvalit: 160.593789 bestmemit:   -1.134528    0.217418
# Summary table
summary(mod3)
## ---------------------------------------------------------------
## Fixed effects for probit(pi) 
## ---------------------------------------------------------------
##             Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)
## (Intercept) -1.13453    0.73291  -1.548   0.1216
## ---------------------------------------------------------------
## Fixed effects for probit(xi) 
## ---------------------------------------------------------------
##             Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)
## (Intercept)  0.21742    0.45876  0.4739   0.6356
## ---------------------------------------------------------------
# we need to apply the inverse link function to obtain the parameters
pnorm(mod3$par)
## (Intercept) (Intercept) 
##   0.1282865   0.5860588
